Problem:
Consider an electrical circuit where the output voltage \\( V(t) \\) across a capacitor depends on the input current \\( I(t) \\) according to the integral transformation \\( V(t) = \\int_0^t e^{-(t-s)/RC} I(s) \\, ds \\), where R and C are constants representing the resistance and capacitance, respectively.

If an intervention changes the input current \\( I(t) \\) midway at time \\( t_1 \\) to a different constant function, will the output voltage at any later time \\( T > t_1 \\) still depend on the original input current before \\( t_1 \\)?
Explanation: Despite the change in the input current at \\( t_1 \\), the output voltage at any time T > \\( t_1 \\) still reflects the influence of the initial segment of \\( I(t) \\) from 0 to \\( t_1 \\) due to the integral's dependence over the entire interval from 0 to T. Each part of the input current contributes to the final output voltage.
